bibl.title: Despatch from John H. Smyth to John Hay
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p:
Consulate General of the United States,
Monrovia, Liberia, Apr. 28, 1880.
Mr. J. H. Smyth to The Ass't Secretary of State.
Shipwrecked passengers & crew of the English steamer "American", rescued by an American bark.
The Emma F. Herriman of Boston, Captain Upton, rescues the passengers and crew of the "American", 150 miles S.W. of Cape Palmas.

Consulate General of the United States,
Monrovia, Liberia, Apr. 28, 1880.
On the 28th of April, 1880, Captain Joseph Upton of the Bark Emma F. Herriman of Boston, Mass., from Gaboon, arrived off Monrovia for the purpose of discharging Kroomen.

At a distance of 150 miles S.W. of Cape Palmas–three boats were met by the Herriman having on board passengers & crew = 65 persons–from the English steamer "American", from South Hampton bound to the Cape
Hon. John Hay,
Ass't Secretary of State,
Washington, D.C.
Cape of Good Hope.
The steamer having had her main shaft broken, foundered and went down, at a distance of 250 or 300 miles S.W. of Palmas.
The Captain took these unfortunates aboard, and conveyed them to Grand Bassam, where they embarked on the British and African steamer Cranza.
No lives were lost, but all were very much exhausted and in peril–having been at sea after the foundering of the vessel, for 2 days.
Captain Joseph Upton is of the firm of Upton & Stephens of Danoe Beachtown.

I am, Sir,
Your obd't serv't,
Jno H Smyth,
U.S. Consul General.
